Unexpected is the first thing I thought upon stumbling upon Myself;Yourself. I learned eventually that it's based upon a Visual Novel, though that became obvious as most VNs tend to have similar structure (a main character, 4 or 5 heroines and a boy side character). Now when I say unexpected I mean I was truly thinking it was just another harem series, love triangle drama, or worse a complete waste of time.
Fortunately, it's not. It's actually pretty good. The main character, Sana, is not really terrible or dull like most MCs, though he is not that interesting either. The story is made incredibly interesting bythe interactions of the side characters. Nanaka is the main heroine but is traumatized by a certain event from her childhood, the twins are constantly suffering because of the relationship of their step-mother and their father, and even some dramatic and deeply emotional moments concerning certain characters I would loathe to spoil.


All of this drama is perfectly disguised as your typical slice of life high school story. And that is a good thing. You will be surprised by the first few episodes that these characters have much to tell you. I awkwardly liked Hinako the most, since she became an inmediate favorite: her "I am an adult" behavior is amazingly cute, and she goes through a simple yet very sweet arc. 


Maybe my favorite thing was how effective the music was, not only the opening and ending themes but several sound tracks still play in my head as I write this. I also enjoyed how the story handled some very complicated real world problems involving trauma, depression, and family abuse. Maybe the mish-mash of everything might feel bloated at times, but I feel everything was touched upon with the right amount of time. 


One of my few complaints is how the story unfolds. But believe me, they come as personal preferences and not diminish the quality of the story, which I think is very solid and overal very good. 


If you want a simple drama anime with cute girls and some mature topics mixed in, I really recommend this. Unfortunately, there is nothing beyond this anime, which sucks because an OVA would have been great...

Myself ; Yourself, a Drama, Romance and School genre Anime. A boy named Sana returns to his home town after 5 years later due to his parent's business plans. It is quiet similar to other animes, a person comes back to their town and explores their missing memory's from what has happened before.
Story - 8
I have to say, the Story is not great, but it is also not bad. Nothing unique or special will happen in it that will affect your emotions towards it. The first few episodes explains a few basic things of what has happened, so you just flow with the story. Butthe end is really where the twist is.

I am quite surprised that all this was produced into 13 episodes, the ending was not rushed so it is good. But i don't think the anime had brought out the full potential of the story, many other things could still be used or put into it. So the anime is partly lacking. But i think the anime could have been produced up to around 24 episodes if it was more perfect.


Art - 8

The art in this anime is very basic so it does very well suit this anime. The background is not very detailed though, but i guess that its because this anime was made back in 2007. Even though the art is not highly detailed, it should still be able to entertain you. I do like the way how they designed the characters though, nothing is bad about them, none of those silly oversized features such as the eyes.


Sound - 9

I personally found the OP cute, i enjoyed it all the way close to the end. But then it does get sort of annoying afterwards towards the end. The ED song was quite good, pretty much a slideshow of pictures, but very good chosen pictures for the mood of the song from the anime.

The music during the anime were also lacking some moods of the scenes, so some music didn't really suit the mood. But most of the time, the music blended into the mood.


Character - 8

I enjoyed how the characters behaved in this anime because it's pretty much every high school friend you ever had, such as, a talkative comedic friend, a shy friend, etc. So it really does remind you of your high school days. Not much is lacking from the Characters, they contribute well to the anime. Their rolls are used very well to explain and do things.

But.. i have to admit.. in the anime, Aoi Oribe has one of the most irritating voices i have ever heard in my whole entire life. 


Enjoyment - 8

I did enjoy this anime pretty much all the way to the end. Nothing was rushed to complete the ending, so i am happy how they organised the story into 13 episodes. It may be slow paced to some viewers, but everything starts to unfold smoothly towards the end.


Overall - 9

This Anime is not bad for a romance anime, also not as good too. But it is enjoyable to everyone. Easy and basic layout so its easy to understand from start to finish. I honestly think that the story could have some more improvements though.

But besides all that, this anime is enjoyable if you are looking for something with romance in it.

I honestly LOVE this anime! It has a very beautiful story!
It is unique in a way, at least how I see it.. Overall it was absolutly OUTSTANDING!

Sooo this is my first review on MAL, and my first anime review in general. I'm use to reviewing tech and music so this could either go really well or really, really bad.
Anyway, let me preface this by saying that I am still relatively new to anime. I watched Death Note about 5 years ago and that was it, it was only until December last year, when I started watching Bakemonogatari that I bought a Crunchyroll subscription, and since I've been watching different shows everyday. However, this is the first romance series I've watched.
Story; The thing this show does very well is how long itcan draw out it's story. For the first half of the show, very little happens episode to episode but it gives you JUST enough to want to watch the next episode. The second half is a little more fast-paced and it contrasts really well with the first. Even though there is a main story, the side stories draw just as much attention, and all contribute really well to the main plot, however you can tell side-plots from main-plot as clear as day. The story progresses from a straight up romance series to something quite dark and dramatic near the end. It doesn't feel like an extremely natural progression in how each revelation plays but nowhere near bad enough to put you off watching. I gave this section an 8/10, because while the story was realistic and well paced, it lacked a little bit of shine to make it feel truly natural.


Art; The art direction is quite different in this show, compared to the other series I have watched, however it works well alongside the story. One thing the animators did spectacularly in this show was the environment, some of the settings in this show are absolutely sublime, real eye-candy, and the same could be said for some of the characters. Nanaka especially, her array of emotions throughout this series are executed astoundingly beside her art, the first time she smiles, you smile. When she cries near the middle of the series it broke my heart, and her broodiness is actually done pretty well too (especially when it's very easy to make a broody character extremely annoying). Sana, on the other hand, has to be one of the most bland characters (art-wise), I've seen, which is a shame because I do like his character. Obviously having a blandly animated protagonist is quite damaging, hence the 7/10. 


Sound: I'll admit it, I'm a sucker for a good opening theme tune, both inside and outside of anime. The opening theme for this series is brilliant, it's an electro-rock/pop song and the opening animation matches the song fantastically, it's catchy as hell, it makes you wanna tap along, and with all the characters playing along on stage it really does set the stage for each episode.

The credit song however isn't as memorable, not bad, just a little boring. The music throughout the show blends in to the scene, and sometimes I'd not even notice there was music playing because it blended so well. However there was one particular piece in this show that kept getting repeated, again, and again, and again. I know this is standard for a lot of shows but they really overdid it with this piece, and a lot of the times it felt unnecessary.

Character wise, the voice acting is pretty good. Not spectacular, but executed well-enough. Once again, Nanaka stands out here above the rest, while on the other hand Aoi's voice grates on you for the most part, however, you do kind of get used to it, and it does shine every so often. 9/10.


Character: For me, this should be the one that matters most in a show like this, and they don't disappoint. At first, the characters seem kind of bland and one-dimensional, but quickly develop some very complex and very well fleshed-out backgrounds. This is where my earlier point about the show being slightly slow-paced comes into play, things happen awfully slowly at times in this show but when there is a revelation, it really lends itself to the characters, and helps you sympathise with them. Sana, for the most part wanted to make me pull my hair out with how much of an idiot he is. The twins however are two of the most interesting characters in the show and bounce off of each other really well, their conclusion in the story is tragic but sweet. Nanaka as well, while the slowest developing character in the show, explodes at points. Aoi doesn't really develop throughout the show at all, however she is an excellent addition to the story regardless because she feels like a glue between the group. Asami turns out to be more interesting than you first think, and although her revelation is quick, she is an interesting character throughout the whole show, starting as something of an enigma. 9/10 because I fell in love with Nanaka, and could easily see myself as a part of their friends circle.


Enjoyment: This show doesn't grab you. It doesn't demand your interest. It reels you in slowly until the end, and throws you back into the sea every so often just to make you wanna come back for more. I'm watching ERASED right now too and as an example, that show literally holds you at the collar demanding to be watched. I really enjoyed Myself ; Yourself, but a couple of bits feel like blatant filler, I wouldn't worry though because the killer parts make up for it.

Where this show shines is how you can enjoy it naturally, I didn't feel compelled to keep my eyes on the screen the whole time but it's easy to know what's going on in a scene (sometimes even before it happens). 8/10


Overall: As my first romance anime I probably couldn't have picked a more ideal show, because if it was perfect I'd hold every other show up to it, but it isn't perfect. It has flaws and they're quite obvious, but it's a tight story with some excellent characters and development. I'll definitely give this show another spin sometime.


8/10.

WARNING! THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS!
When I started watching this, judging from the picture at anime newsnetwork, seeing all the girls, while reading the main protagonist is a boy, I expected a harem anime. It was already obvious from the start that Sana and Nanaka were gonna get together. However, in the beginning, it looked a bit like Aoi-chan was in love with Sana too when she was blushing in front of him and such. So the when Sana met Hoshino-san and Nanaka got all jealouse and stuff, it fellt like the starts of just another love triangle. But after a few episodes, I became happilysuprised.


Most of the time, 12-13 episode-animes don't really capture me. They're just too short to really get to feel with the characters, but this one did a pretty good job in that. First, it was a nice, enjoyable anime, nothing more though. Things like Nanaka being depressed for unknown reasons, Hinako having a crush on Shuusuke, Shuri bullying the guys and Aoi-chan being way to hyperactive and screaming "Tanoushii this" and "Tanoushii that" with her sqeaky voice got a little annoying after a while, and I started wondering if this was going anywhere. 


When Nanaka's past came out, things got a little more interesting, although the scene of Nanaka crying in Sana's arms and Sana saying stuff like "We'll always be together from now on." still felt a little cheesy to me. As for me, the series really started blooming when the Shuu/Shuri-arc started. From that point on, the several plot-twists and character development really surprised me. For example Hoshino-san's story justified a lot of those things that annoyed me earlier on, because they all made sense all of a sudden, plus, because they made it look like a love triangle at first, the truth was an even bigger shock.


In the end, the character I felt most connected with was Shuri, and I felt a strange desire to have a twin brother like Shuusuke. I kinda missed them during the last two episodes. Nevertheless, the ending did satisfy me a little. =]

For a span of 13 episodes, a show containing both school life and drama often results in melodrama due to the lack of time it takes to properly build a good characters. Unfortunately, myself ; yourself exemplifies this formula. It also doesn't help that our lead male, Sana Hidaka, doesn't really have a knack for grasping a given situation. Top that off with our easily angered lead female, Nanaka Yatsushiro, and we have a perfect ice cream sundae shit storm.
Noting that myself ; yourself only has 13 episodes to play with, how it spent its episodes were rather unproductive by introducing too many sub-plots irrelevantto the main story. While these sub-plots give minor characters a fair amount of screentime and a bit of personality and development, it all becomes irrelevant when the story decides to simple leave said characters behind. If that wasn't bad enough, itfs merely the tip of the iceberg. The minor plot themselves were forcefully introduced by events which seemed to drawn from slips of paper that were randomly pulled from a box of suggestions. One of the ideas pulled from the box was this: Five minutes of screentime are given to minor character Suusuke Wakatsuki walking home from school and saving an elementary school girl from being picked on by a group of other teenage boys. For the next three episodes, let's put aside the main plot to tell a love story about how an elementary school girl had fallen head over heels for a boy twice her age. Myself ; yourself continues to do this for the next six episodes or so.


Consequently this creates a mess of unnecessary melodrama which started from nothing and ending abruptly. Of course, no melodrama would be complete without the genetic love triangle. Except myself ; yourself's love triangle threw in a twist by having one of our characters telling us "oh I wasn't involved in that love triangle lol". It gets points for the unexpected twist but loses points for misleading the audience and wasting time developing something it didn't need too. Oh wait, the entire show was like that.


For characters and development, as previously mentioned, our lead character, Sana, isn't exactly the sharpest knife in the drawer. Unfortunately, this does not change as the show progresses. Then again, can we blame him? After all, he barely had any screentime to develop his character. Throughout the show, we're fed bits of his traumatic past and his bits of our lead female, Nanaka's past. When the two come together for a "resolve", we see a five minute exchange of dialogue which ends abruptly (this show has a tendency to do that) to jump 10 years into the future.


As disappointing as myself ; yourself was, the twists does somewhat drive the story. Since not all events of the story was laid out perfectly, the story threw a bit of a mystery genre in there to keep viewers watching. It's just a shame that the outcomes of said events were far less exciting as the mystery leads one to think due to poor pace and inadequate development.

I really enjoyed watching this series, and that's what it boiled down to. It's been a while since I watched an anime I so thoroughly enjoyed. It's hard to say what exactly made this anime so good, it has some cliches and some generic characters, but it's not the lazy harem anime you might expect from the cover or the basic premise of a high school boy surrounded by various female friends. 
As much as I liked it, it's uneven. The story of Hinako, a 10 and then 11 year old girl who attaches herself to the group, seemed like filler, it was not glaringlybad but it didn't really develop the core characters, and it was a bit offputting that it involved our protagonist trying to hook up a 10-year-old girl with a friend his own age.


The series is also apparently known for its incest content. It definitely is a subplot, but there's nothing explicit, it's implied (albeit heavily). This is no Koi Kaze, it's not all about incest... unless it's a huge issue for you I don't think you'll have a problem with this anime.


All of that said, I loved this series. It's nothing that hasn't been done before, it's just a good drama anime about a circle of high school friends who come of age somewhat painfully. The main characters are just done very well, with good character development and strong storytelling as it concerns the core narrative. It's a series with many great scenes, and that's where its strength is, rather than having a breakthrough style or a completely new story. When the characters have a lighthearted BBQ by the river early in the series, it's just a perfectly executed scene, it does everything it needs to extremely well. A scene or two like that in most episodes, and it made for something very enjoyable.


I can see how people wouldn't like this, and it's definitely got some blemishes, but in terms of personal enjoyment I'd put this one right up there with "Clannad: After Story" although I confess that objectively, it's at least a notch under that level.

So this is my first review, so bear with me. I wrote this because I was really wrong about this series. Thank God that I stuck with it because it's something really good.
OK, so Myself;Yourself is an adaptation of the visual novel of the same name. What we know about VN adaptations are they're generally crappy, with some notable exceptions (*ehem* Clannad). Though this title is not as great as Clannad it is still pretty good on its own.
What I liked about this show is that it surprised me a whole lot.
I really thought that it was just some crappy adaptation. The first few episodesreally gave me that impression. All those jokes that just wasn't funny, the overflowing cliches that was presented and Aoi-chan's voice. *shudders* Seriously, listening to her was like fingernails on blackboards, F-ing annoying.


But by episode 8, all of those concerns went to take a backseat to the story that unraveled. The first few episodes did give us some glimpse into the plot but it wasn't really all that clear but then...


BOOM! The story kicked into high gear. From the conflict between Sana and Nanaka to Sana discovering the letters, that, for me, was the true start of the story. It had so much impact that it made up for the mediocrity of the episodes that preceded it. I actually felt my spine tingle and my body tremble when Nanaka cried in Sana's arms. I was moved and hooked.


Every episode after that just gave us plot twist (homicidal granny) after plot twist (lesbian Asami) after plot twist (Watanuki incest) after plot twist (father arson) after plot twist (suicidal Nanaka and Sana). It was heart-wrenching. It made me sympathize with the characters and feel the pain they were going through. It was because of this that I think of this anime very highly.


Though, this anime isn't perfect. The voice acting was poor, the animation was so-so and the pacing is bad. It would have been better if they cut the first seven episodes into a 2-3 episode span and used the other 10 episodes to expound on the conflict.


The ending was just okay. I felt that it fell flat in the end. They could have done better than cutting to ten years after and trying to vaguely tie up the plot holes but I think it was fitting with respect to the series. Personally, I wished that there was a kiss between Nanaka and Sana.


I recommend Myself;Yourself to people who like a good romance/drama anime. I am sure you'll appreciate it. Although some patience is needed, but if you can bear waiting this series will reward you.

I don't really write these very often, but I want more people to enjoy this one.
Firstly this one is a tragedy and a romance. 
 The animation is very average and this anime doesn't even have an opening, much less a good one, but where this anime excels however is it's plot. It's not unpredictable, or anything of that nature, but everything was were it needed to be. The characters were great and you feel a heavy attachment to most of them, and they complement the story well. The feelings in this one are on par with Ano Hana, andyou get the same sad yethappy feeling from it. Fair warning though like the original Clanned the story has a slow start. I highly recommend Myself ; Yourself.

The first thing you notice when you begin watching Myself;Yourself is that of the art style. The long faced style of the characters, simple designs and non-distinguished clothing can be a rather large turn off to the viewer. Likewise the passable animation quality can be annoying to a viewer that wants everything to be a work of art. From simply animating more than just the characters hands clapping, or lip sync the show lacks a lot of what one could find beautiful. This is most aptly shown by the opening of the show, which utilizes a concert scene. Similar scenes in other shows use accurateand elegant animation to the music which often astounds the audience. Yet in Myself;Yourself you merely get the energy of the characters movement portrayed, not the actual instruments played. Which as it sounds doesn't make the show hard to watch, it merely does not draw you in as strongly as it could otherwise do.


The music used in the show is pretty forgettable. None of the musical tracks carry any mood badly though, they are just merely there and don't give lasting impressions to the viewer. Despite having small musical sub themes which could lead to disappointment to a viewer that wanted any music the characters themselves play as being truly moving. In a similar fashion the sound assets and voice acting isn't out of place as a whole, but neither is it anything amazing. Overall the production values of animation and sound are completely passable, but nothing amazing, or good.


Luckily, production values aside, the actual characters in this show are quite solidly portrayed. That is, the majority of the main cast act like people, their quirks are understandable and lifelike which makes connecting to these characters, despite the visual lack of typical distinctions, easy. This isn't necessarily true for all the characters in the show, but being as it's a 13 episode series this is to be expected. In fact the brief time they give to some of the lesser characters I would argue is time that would have been better put towards  portraying the plot specific characters as this would have strengthened their already well crafted characters and allow the audience a deeper connection to the characters that matter. The characters carry this show, with themes and relationships which are so easy to do wrong either by putting too much or too little emphasis on them, are done wonderfully. Truly drawing the audience in to the main experiences the show has to offer.


The plot of the show is nothing special. That is, there is nothing that happens that is really that surprising outside of maybe a couple of twists. Yet I cannot call this a bad thing as the narrative and characters make sense. They don't tend to do stupid things that a person would not do. The struggles and triumphs shown in the series are fairly realistic and understandable if bordering on fairy tale-like at times. Nothing happens in the show that one wouldn't expect to be possible in real life, no super natural phenomena just people being people. The comedic sides of the show are pretty typical, with gags that one has seen a thousand times before. Yet they centre around one particular supporting character and don't take away from the rich immersion of the actual plot and feeling of the show. The overall tones of the show vary from light-hearted to dark dramatic. This isn't used to it's full potential but it is used well enough that the viewer cares about what happens. This isn't a show that repulses you when you watch some of the gags, but neither is it a show that will make you laugh out loud often. Nor will it send you into crying for hours on end, but it will dabble in both 

not dedicating itself to central emotion.


Thus I would have to conclude that Myself;Yourself is a solid drama. Very little in the show is actually done bad, yet very little in the show actually stands out as being amazing outside of it's mature usage of themes and characterization. Whilst it takes about episode three for the show really to get rolling and a lot more feels like it could have been better, in either more time spent on some characters, some plot lines explored in more detail, or even using less obvious foreshadowing to give a more surprising plotline. For a 13 episode romantic comedy drama the show is worth watching if you enjoy that style of show.

An anime that shows its true colors towards the end of the series; and those colors are vibrant and true. In many ways did I find this anime to be average in terms of entertainment. However, the depth to the characters are what the show portrays quite well, for I also believe that was the major purpose of this anime. So please do not expect any X's or O's.
It is worth watching until the end for only then may one fully appreciate what this anime was about, since that's how I feel being that I finished the series just now.

After watching all of the episodes, I can't help but feel that so much more could have been done. 13 episodes was just simply not enough to really do the series justice. 
What this anime did do well lay mostly in the characters. It was obvious to me that all of the characters had reasons behind their actions and the personalities of each one felt different and refreshing. The deep, emotional scenes between Sana and Nanaka especially add depth to the anime, as a whole. This was the highlight of the series for me.
Unfortunately, the series did feel hurried in the latter part of theanime which, for me, ruined a lot of the tension that had been built up throughout the previous episodes. I also felt that the back story of Sana was not as well laid out as the rest of the characters which made him feel a bit flimsy in comparison with some of the more minor characters.\n
Still, I did enjoy the anime and have no qualms with adding it to my completed list. For any fan of slice of life who enjoys the tugging of heartstrings, this is not a bad anime to peruse.

If someone would ask me what Myself;Yourself is all about, it's all about characters having PTSD. I think 13 episodes are not enough to explain the story line fully since some scenes seemed to be forced. The ending doesn't resolve any character flaws and some character's personality seemed to be not developed, instead, jumped to 'high spike', having a story behind it instantly.
Its comedy part didn't fit at all. Sure it's fun to watch, but it is not enough to be that entertaining. It's like 80% drama and 20% comedy, although I liked how did it approach the 'slice of life' genre.

In recent times, it's a challenge to find an anime that doesn't use recycled themes over and over again. To me, accidentally stumbling upon Myself;Yourself while randomly browsing crunchyroll is like finding a hidden gem amidst mainstream anime. While Myself;Yourself starts out as if it's your typical run-of-the-mill slice of life school romance anime with hints of harem... if you stick to it for a while... it isn't.
Story
Starting off with the return of the MC to his hometown, the beginning episodes felt as if it's a normal slice-of-life school anime with probable harem and love triangle. But as the series progresses, it starts to developas something that's not quite the norm. The drama, conflict left a strong impact which finally strikes at the end point of episode 11.   The pacing felt right, except perhaps for the last arc of the story. 


Art & Sound

No complaints for the art, not too bad but not too good either. The voice acting was generally great, but perhaps Aoi's voice is a bit too high-pitched and hence, annoying. Causing me to feel somewhat annoyed when she speaks.


Character

The characters are all unique. While at first glance each character seemingly fit into a certain stereotype, as the series progresses, their inner self and problems are brought out into the open. Revealing things we didn't expect when first starting the show. The protagonist threw me off, I expected him to be a normal, dense, and harem material high-school boy, but throughout the series, it is hinted that he is more than that. What didn't sit well with me was perhaps the purpose of having Aoi as a character there.


Enjoyment

Expecting this to be a run-of-the-mill romance school slice of life anime, when the fireworks started, it kinda threw me off. But, after coping with this, it is very enjoyable. One scene in particular (in episode 11), left a very lasting impression on me.


Overall

It's a great watch, especially for those who are bored of the generic anime these days.

I'll start by saying this anime was way better than I was expecting it to be.
The story was awesome. It was very deep, it constantly had me interested in finding out what happens next. The deepness could probably be compared to Clannad, except if this went on longer, maybe it would be even better.
Art had a similar feeling to anime like Clannad but also reminded me of School Days. So, really it's nothing special but there are definitely times when major attention to detail is obvious, and those times are when the art really shines for Myself; Yourself.
Sound: Again, it was fine, but nothing great.Music was okay. Nothing bad about the voice acting either. Oh, I'll say this though. Aoi's voice is so adorable!!\n\n
Characters: As mentioned before, the story was really deep... And this series focuses a lot on the relationships between characters. So it's probably the storytelling of the characters' relationships with each other that makes this as good as it is.\n\n
So overall, I really enjoyed this series. It's a shame it was only 13 episodes, I think a bit more could have been done with it. In fact, an "Afterstory" would be perfect for a show like this.

Yet again im going to stray a bit from my usual style of reviews.
Myself; Yourself is an interesting title. I've heard/read from a bunch of different sources and eventually added it to my watch list. This show earns the heart drop award. Meaning it's great at just dropping the ball straight on you. Before watching this show I did play through the game. Small comparisons might be used.
Now let's get into the real meat of this review
[Story] 6/10 - Now im sure the synopsis can do this part for me. But the story kinda jumps a lot. Making the real tone of the show dropquiet significantly. Once you get to around episode 7 or 8 the story starts to get a lot better. From that point on the story is pretty good, nothing I haven't heard of or seen before but it was nice to see a story keep my attention this well.


[Art] 8/10 - As this is a bit of an oldie the art style is a bit dated, but it's not ugly. Not in the slightest. It's nice to look at, the animation is overall pretty decent. There are a couple of clippy frames that just seem off, especially when there is more than one character on screen. But they are minor and really don't distract from the show. 


[Sound] 8/10 - The only thing bad about the show's sound is the OP and the ED. They just don't fit the show. Really can't say why as this is a spoiler free review but you will come to see the same if you end up picking this up. An amazing commendation is how they use music to make a scene better. There are plenty of scenes that use some serious visual story telling without music, and they hit hard. Especially in the later half of the show.


[Character] 7/10 - I feel as if the creators did a decent job with character development. It was spread around quite well. Though 1 or 2 characters who are portrayed as supporting roles but are actually main characters. Said characters needed a couple scenes to flesh out their character. If you want a better understanding of the characters, go play the PS2 Game. That does an amazing job at character development.


[Enjoyment] 10/10 - As usual I seem to find yet another guilty pleasure. This anime made me sad, real sad. And I loved it. Sometimes you just need that punch in the gut. Keeping ones attention is really key and I feel like this did a very good job at that.


[Overall Score] 7/10 - Poor story and character really drag this down. Those are it's flaws, simple and swift. If you want a sad story pick this up. Do I recommend this? Yeah. It was a good experience. 


If it's your birthday today, Happy Birthday!

All of ya have a nice rest of your day!

What an emotional roller coaster.
Myself; Yourself is about Hidaka Sana, who left his hometown as a kid and came back five years later and tries to reunite with his friends.
At first I thought it would be him trying to find them and reunite them one by one kind of like AnoHana but I was wrong, the group are still friends, they just had a lot of shit happen while he wasn't around, he finds out about these things gradually throughout the series while having some fun times, tough times and very sad times.
I loved the premise for this story and the development was steady andslow throughout all 13 episodes, they didn't wast time on "solving misunderstandings" and beach and onsen episodes, instead they went for actual romantic developments (although slow) and slight occasional fanservice that still provided fun story development.


The characters were mostly rich and had their backstory established (with a few exceptions ofc, but that didn't really affect the story development nor the enjoyment). But Aoi's voice is a curse, I got on my nerves, good thing she wasn't around too much lol


The art was okay, it's from 2007 so it can only look so good ( although Gurren Lagann begs to differ lol)


The music was good, I liked the OP, ED, and the OST fits in nicely with the story.


I really enjoyed Myself; Yourself. the music was good, the story was touching, and the characters felt relatable. The ending was kind of rushed as we didn't get to see a proper where are they now but only a glimpse of, it did leave some loose ends but it was okay and was still satisfying.



 it was gr8 m8 I r8 8

From my perspective, as a person just getting into anime, this series has been quite enjoyable. I have watched animes of many generes, and quite a sufficient amount on each genre, to say that this particular "slice of life" anime is good for its genre. 
     The situation of some of the people within the series are ones that we can relate to, such as the main characters issue of having to move away a lot due to family/work issues and being bullied. However, there are other less socially-acceptable topics ranging from incest to suicidal attempts/thoughts.The power of "love", from what I feel that the anime is telling me, is what keeps two individuals on the path of suicide from comitting the act. The fact that music is also one of the ways they express their emotions/love is really interesting, since the main violin melody is very packed with emotions. Overall this anime is worth your time since it's definitely not going to bore you, and there are enough conflicts to keep you entertained and also things that are relatable to the average person out there.

Ugh, lots of mixed feelings about this one.
Story: Nothing really happens until after half the series. At least for me, nothing really hooked me in until then. It's very slow-paced. The beginning felt boring. It was mostly the characters hanging out and going to school with mini foreshadowings. The plot twists are either predictable or make you go "No way!". It's pretty much hit or miss. Surprising as they can be, they can be hard to sit through. I did not really like the end because I felt it could have been spread out a bit more instead of tying up the loose ends ina rushed way within the last episode. 


Art: Pretty good, clean and consistent. Probably the best thing of this series and a huge reason people wanted to watch this.


Sound: A couple of the bgm songs were okay, felt like getting the ost after finishing the series. Opening and ending songs were definitely keepers. They were pretty rocking songs. As for the voice actors they were fine. There was a pretty good lineup of recognizable ones. I only have a problem with Aoi's voice... it is so high and annoying. Seriously, every time she's on screen, I brace myself. I don't have anything against the voice actor but... ah, you'll know what I mean if you decide to watch this.


Character: Here's a main problem with this series. I can't really say if they were brilliantly written or just kind of lame.


Sana - He's not really the main that goes around trying to fix everything, he'd like to but the other characters keep to themselves most of the time. I don't have much of a problem with him except on two occasions. Especially at the end, it made me respect him less because his problem is shown to us in a rushed way. A bit much to handle all at once. We know he has a problem but we don't know what it is until the last episode... My other problem with him is the way he reacts to certain things. One is regarding Asami but it's a spoiler so we'll leave it at that.


Nanaka - I could understand what's up with her in episode 1 but she has a lot of mood swings and it gets a little annoying as she doesn't really get her facts straight first so she's either angry at times or very content. Plus, they don't really establish what's up with her until much later in the series.


Aoi - Annoying, go away.


Asami - I thought you were cool...


Shuri and Shuusuke - I really wish they weren't brother and sister, they were written pretty well and it was nice seeing how they take care of each other. Their story was pretty gripping.


Hinako - I liked her more than some of the other characters but she just wasn't important enough. I know she's younger and all but she really had no influence on the plot. She just took up two episodes and made them all about her.


Enjoyment: I don't know what kept me watching, maybe because of the little hints that something would eventually happen or the high expectations I had so I stuck with it. It started to pick up after halfway but the end was so rushed. Can't say I hated it or it was as bad as other things I've seen. This could've been pretty good, it just wasn't carried out properly. I also wish there was more romance between the two main characters. You know something'll happen for these two but no hand holding and no kiss...


Overall: It is slow but if you can sit through the first 8 episodes you'll do fine or ask someone who did watch it and skip the Hinako episodes to save you time as you won't be missing anything. The drama is kind of worth it but to be honest, this Anime is definitely not for everyone.


Thank you for reading my review. Feedback would be greatly appreciated. Hope this helped.

Myself; Yourself is a dense and subtle anime.  The story revolves around a boy who returns to his childhood hometown, and his renewed relationships with his old friends.
Have you ever heard a deadpan joke before?  A statement that you took seriously, was given fairly seriously, but there are hints that it's a joke somewhere?  In Myself; Yourself, what seems like cliche is actually subtle parody.  That's not to say that it doesn't conform to genre.  It's just that when "big breasted moe girl" appears, that's exactly what she is.  It's a little over the top.  Other instances inthe anime are when Sana falls on Hinako.  The first time you see that, you think it's corny cliche.  The third time, you should understand it's parody.  This is also made very clear when "anime blue" and company appear.


This is a mature anime.  It's not rife with fanservice or bad language or lewdness.  But it touches on trust and betrayal and jealousy.  On love and pain.  On dealing with hard times.


The plot in Myself; Yourself isn't always in front of you.  It's in the periphery.  Your understanding of events and conversations that happened earlier in the story will change as more is revealed later.  An example of this is Syusuke's answers to the questions Sana brings him from Hinako.


This is an anime that, when it is done, benefits from some post-viewing pondering.  As you begin to walk back the cat, these elements of peripheral plot and parody show themselves more clearly.  This show also has a high rewatch potential (especially given it's length).


Myself; Yourself is worth watching (maybe even twice!).

Don't be fooled like I was... I went into this thinking it would be light-hearted... it wasn't really. But it's still really good!
Only one event kind of blindsided me, but I suppose they even had hints leading up to that, but it was still pretty obscure, and I don't like things to happen just out of nowhere, it makes it seem like they just threw stuff in for the hell of it. 
The rest of the plot and events are all led up to pretty well though.
All in all, if you're looking for a nice drama this is a good one.

So Myself; Yourself has a not-so-original story concept to start off with. But that doesn't keep it from giving a decent story though. It starts off with Sana experienceing a flashback of his childhood the day before he left to move to Tokyo. Flash forward 5 years and Sana has moved back to his hometown of Sakuranomori where he lives in a boarding house that is owned by one of his friends, Aoi. Sana soon finds out about his friends over the last 5 years and eventually gets slapped by a girl named Nanaka. This drives the story throughout the whole series as Sana triesto figure out the missing pieces of his past and his friend's past.


Now the series is okay for what it's worth. But the reason why I gave it all 7's is because there are points where the predictable sets in and points where things just don't sit right and can be down right, disturbing.


SPOILER ALERT!!!


For instance, Sana gets rather friendly with a girl named Hoshino, who helps her with student council meetings, but the weird part comes from the fact that Hoshino was in love with a friend of his, Shuri, who is a girl. Coming from nowhere kind of threw me for a loop. Which was sort of weird as well as intriguing since you don't really see it that much.


Another weird staple is that eventually, the twins, Shuu and Shuri run away together after their father tries to seperate them after the sister disrespects their stepmother. But that's not all, someone drew a love umbrella on a chalk board at school (it turned out to be Hoshino), that resembled the twin's incest love which wasn't there. This lead them to run away together, almost enforcing that incest and when the time jump occurs later on, they are seen walking in holding hands together. Hmmm. Seems sort of ecchi.


One more flaw in this series is that you can see the problems Sana suffered before it is revealed in the end. Sana tried to commit suicide after some bullying lead him to slit his wrist. Ever since then, he wore a watch to cover it and was frightened whenever he sees blood. And later on, Nanaka seems to want to do the same thing after her unfortunate events and reveals his dark secret to her. But that part was all too recognizable around at least 5 episodes prior to that whole scene. C'mon, some mystery would be nice once in a while.


And the final preverbial nail in the coffin comes from the interconnections that occur between every character in the series. Not only do all of the students know each other, but the new teacher knew Sana from her childhood. This is all too boring to me. It was like "Oh yay, she knew him 10 years ago. Why is this episode even here?" It could have been removed and still kept it's continuity fresh in the end of the series.


Enough with the flaws now. This was still something good to watch intermittently. The characters are still pretty solid with some good background. The concepts for each character's background is pretty original with some fairly good plot twists that made me jump for a little bit. I'd only recommend it for those of you who are just wanting something to watch if you're kind of bored and would want a general decent anime for those rainy Sundays.

Myself ; Yourself is another romance/ drama/ comedy anime, but different (also a lot better) than most other shows of this variety:
Story:
The story is the stereotypical "boy returns to home town and meets old childhood friends" scenario, but what makes this show really good is that it's entertaining and fun to watch, even without huge cliff hangers. In a lot of other drama animes the protagonists often do stupid things or are in situations where they should talk but don't, which makes those types of show extremely unnerving - this doesn't happen too often during this show and occurs less and less as the showprogresses.

There is a perfect balance between romance and actual story telling during this show, though I wouldn't expect too much romance. There are quite a lot of dramatic twists in the story too, which, combined with the flashbacks, reveal more about each character, making their motives and feelings more understandable.

Still, the story looses some points for having quite a number of fillers, which are absolutely unnecessary in a 13 episode series. I would also argue that the first 5 episodes could have been fit into 2 and the last episodes were far too short.

But the biggest plus to this anime is its end, although a lot of people may disagree. I really hate it when drama anime end with one big bang, and that's it. It leaves you with a very unsatisfying feeling. This show though builds up to the climax very slowly and arrives at it about 4 minutes before the show ends, leaving enough time for the story to slowly end. The climax isn't even the actual relationship, as it often tends to be in romance anime. It's as if the show drives on 2 rails, one being the romance part and one the actual story. The story slowly ends, but the romance part goes on for a bit more until the show finishes. I'd best describe the end as "soothing".


Animation:

The animation was OK I guess. At no point did the animation bother me, nor did it really fascinate me with its beauty.


Sound:

The music in this anime is quite good. Both the opening and the ending songs are very joyful, making a good start and end to each episode. The music during the anime itself fits well to each situation. What I found great was the violin playing of one of the protagonists. It really gave a great start and finish to the show.


Character:

The characters are very fleshed out. The show really leaves nothing to question about any character.


Entertainment:

This show was very entertaining. The "mysteries" about the 2 main characters past made me curious to see what really had happened and left me in suspense, which is great, since most romance anime only build suspense upon the relationships of characters.


Overall:

You'll definitely not regret watching this show. But don't expect too much romance, since in comparison to shows like "True Tears" there isn't much. The feelings in this anime flow through the story telling, not the love stories. I really enjoyed this show.

Story 10, Art 10, Sound 10, Characters 8, Enjoyment 8, and Overall, its a 7
Im a little rusty, its been a little while since ive seen it, but Ill give you what I can out of memory, and some notes I have...
Story 10
I love the basic synopsis of a guy having a thing for a girl, leaving his home for a good while, only to come back and have to start back from scratch, while shes ready to pick up where they left off... I guess I like it so much because I can relate to it, thanks to similar things happening in my ownlive, but even despite that, I think its a good basic plot for an anime


Art 10

Typical well budgeted anime, good picture... doesnt qualify for "state of the art" but its right there, and I cant see any reason to knock it down... to me, the art and sound dont really carry any value for the final score anyway...


Sound 10

Pretty much all I can remember is the OP and ED music [again... no effect on the final score]... I love the OP... its very fun to listen to, and I do like to hear it every now and again... the ED song made me want to pour bleach in my ear... no reason other than I just didnt like it... there is a character voice issue I had, but I decided to address that in the next section


Characters 8

Voice issue - I promise, no hate to the seiyuu, I just happen to hate this particular trope... the character Aoi Oribe has voice characteristics that sound like moe went to a super saiyan level... its about as whimsical as elmo and ive never heard a real person talk that way, even in Japan... now that thats out of the way, the rest of the characters are decent... I feel theyre pretty typical, but theyre decent, and I have very few complaints about the rest of them... I feel that this bit of emo stuff wasnt really necessary, but its not out of the realm of possibility, and some of the reasoning behind it was a little overdramatic, tho some people really are overdramatic, and in worse ways, so Ill buy it, it just wasnt my cup of tea...


Enjoyment 8

I did overall enjoy the anime... its not really my first choice recommendation, but if you need something to watch, it might keep you entertained... I know in this review, I complain a fair bit about the drama, but there are good points to it too, Im just hoping not to spoil... I did enjoy the level of romance in this anime... its there, but its not totally in your face...


Overall 7

I call it a 7, because I do feel something is missing, but I just dont know how to manifest it into words... again, it has been a little while since ive seen it, so theres a good chance ill update or rewrite this review... but all in all, I think it is worth seeing, but maybe theres something else on your view list you might enjoy better seeing first

Overall	
A cute but very divided story. There are many good ideas in here, but they are badly carried out with poor directing, poor animation and pretty indifferent voice acting.
All in all, this could have been good, but it isn't. I heard the game is better, though.
Animation	
Backgrounds and general design looks pretty good, with nice visuals like sakura, sunbeams, lighting effects and similar. However, when it comes to animation, movement, poses, facial expressions and stuff that are supposed to make the story come alive, most of it looks stiff and unnatural. It's really annoying since each still frame looks good, but animated, it is a failure.Too bad.


Sound	

Voice acting is another bad point in Myself, Yourself. Some characters sound good, like Aoi and Shuri, but others (most notably the main character Sana) sound really dull and amateurish.


The music, on the other hand, is generally good. Background soundtrack is kind of varied and fits the mood. The ending track is so-so, but the opening theme is amazeballs. Probably a top 10 if you ask me.


Story	

The story is not very one-directional. Every character has their own little side-story, but they are not really connected to each other. Each sub-plot could have been an entirelly separate anime, but competing over the same screen time, they all feel rushed and incomplete.


Wierd, because there are some animes of equal length that managed to tell a much larger story in a satisfying way. AIR comes to mind.


Character	

All the main characters have at least some depth and get rather well developed during the episodes, even though the development feels a bit rushed. The characters' subplots aren't really connected to each other, which is a shame.


Side characters are generally well used and integrated into the different plots. I specially liked the homeroom teacher. Even though she is a stereotype (why are all anime teachers so hot?).


Value	

I watched the [SHiN-gx] fansubs, which were pretty rotten. The [B-G_&_m.3.3.w] ones seemed better, but most of the files were corrupt and wouldn't play properly. 


While watching anime, you should always try to read between the lines, but bad grammar and stupid wordings don't really add to the experience.

Length: 13 Episodes
Original Airdates: 9/07 - 12/07
Demographic: Seinen
Genres: Romance, Drama, Comedy, Slice of Life
One Sentence Description: "Proof that a rom-com can end up dark and amazing"
Plot Synopsis
Sana Hikada returns to his hometown after 5 years away living in Tokyo. Although there are some changes to the town, most has remained the same. On a detour to his apartments, he notices a girl in a shrine maiden outfit watching him when he visits the shrine. He finds out, the next day at school, that this girl is actually Nanaka Yatsushiro, his old childhood friend whom he gave a bracelet to before he left, that she stillwears, even to this day.\n
(From Anime News Network)\n\n
Personal Opinion\n
First off... apparently anime characters bleed black blood nowadays... =/\n
Back to topic, Myself; Yourself has gotten a lot of comparisons to another anime named "School Days"... Now if you've read about the ending of School Days, then this comparison should be sounding alarms in your head. Fortunately... I can say that the endings aren't similar. \n
Myself; Yourself starts off like a typical romance/harem/comedy.  A moderate sized cast made up of 2 guys and a lot of girls.  You see the possibility of 3 girls liking the main character.  However this formula gets shattered by the 8th episode as the anime takes a turn for the darker.\n
Now when I say darker... i don't mean like "heads will roll" kinda dark (that's just f***ed up), i more mean like the pasts and backgrounds of the characters are shown and the happy athmosphere of the first 7 episodes disappear.\n
The first 7 episodes were somewhat flawed but really helped me appreciate each character. (Aoi-chan is just tooo cute). It's the final 5-6 episodes that this anime REALLY shines. All the major character developments occur hear and most of these are emotionally touching.\n
The final episode closes the anime nicely and leaves the viewer satisfied\n\n
I personally would've liked to see some of the secondary characters to get some character development. But i'll take what i get\n\n
RATING: 8/10\n\n
Similar to...\n
- Kanon\n
Many girls who have some problems in their past or present\n\n
- Shigofumi\n
the 2nd half the series really targeted the faults of humans in general and almost felt like the writer was making a commentary.

12 Episodes. After 12 of the 13 episodes, I had pretty much made up my mind on the series. I had even thought of most of what I was going to say in my review of it. By in large, the characters were either bland or their actions half the time (Nanaka) didn't make any sense. It seemed like it was trying to have some kind of deeper plot going on below the surface, but it wasn't really clicking. There was a definite lack of focus, something that a show with only 13 episodes really cannot afford to have, in my opinion.
But the 13th episode....thatwas pretty good. While I think a bad ending can ruin a really good show, this is the first time I think I can say that a really good ending improved an otherwise mediocre show. The twists at the end, were great. It completely caught me off guard when I learned what actually happened to Nanaka, and the scenes following the reveal were very touching. As I watched Sana, for the first time I really felt for him and the situation he was in. After I finished that last episode I wanted to stand up and say "this is what the entire show should've been like!"


While never really bad, Myself ; Yourself really struggles through most of the series. Two episodes are dedicated to a character who almost never appears outside of those episodes, and many of the other episodes spend a lot of time focusing on supporting characters. I'll reiterate that the show suffers from a lack of focus, and while there is the occasional moment or two in which I went "neat, didn't see that coming" the plot largely was predictable and sometimes boring. The characters were a bit better, but not anything beyond good; I am grateful that Nanaka did start making more sense as the series went on. But the ending, the ending at least was done right.


I wouldn't call Myself ; Yourself a romance, and if you are looking for romance this isn't the place. If you're a fan of Drama and Slice of Life, this might be a decent show to watch. But don't expect a lot beyond decent. The ending, while great, doesn't make up for 12 episodes that came before it. Still, with only 13 episodes I could think of worse ways to pass the time, and it's not the worse anime I've ever seen. If you do start it, try to make it to the ending.

Sana Hidaka a sixteen year old high school student returns to his hometown Sakuranomori after five years, re-united with his childhood friends Nanaka, Aoi, Shusuke and Shuri. Sana attempts to return to the life he once had in his hometown, but time has changed Sakuranomori and its inhabitants as secrets and past memories haunt the five friends that could very well decimate their once peaceful and happy lives. 
This anime started off incredibly slow when introducing the characters and going over past events had taken place which took up a good few episodes. As the series progressed it gave hints of events that had happenedprior to the present date without actually telling us what they are and how they happened. As the show came to a close it showed the full extent of what had happened in those five years and along the way we deal with cute crushes, broken friendships, family conflicts and separation.  


The story is mainly centered on Sana and Nanaka, the relationship that they had when in their younger days and the jagged, broken friendship that they currently have. As the story progresses they try rebuild their shattered relationship, uncover dark repressed memories and look to the future for better days that lie ahead. 


I was left very disappointed with the slow start of this anime that I dropped it five episodes in only to return to finish it several months later. This series continued with its slow pace just as I had left it and only at episode eight and nine that things had started to get interesting. Questions had been answered, but the thing that annoys me is that why they couldn’t have revealed some of this information sooner rather than show me at the very end.


A lot of people would be tempted to drop this show as no real drama occurs until later episodes which can be quite off putting for viewers, though when the drama and secrets unfold satisfaction will be granted. 


Other than main characters Sana and Nanaka we have Aoi who doesn't really play that big of a role in the series and is just there for the sake of it. The others are twins Shusuke and Shuri who lost their mother at a young age found comfort in each other as their farther was occupied with work. They have a strong relationship but others see it as more than just brother and sister. Soon rumors spread about the two and they are forced into making some tough decisions. 


The soundtrack for this anime is not half bad, I particularly enjoy the combination of piano and violin and the opening and closing songs are good and quite enjoyable though at some point you will skip them as it gets boring. 


This anime has been compared to the likes of Kanon 2006 which I am not particularly pleased about. Myself;Yourself does show some similarities to Kanon, but the two are nothing alike as the character designs are the only real similarity, adopting the stereotypical moe design. Overall this anime was ok; it was a good shot at the romance/drama anime but falls flat with its slow pacing and satisfying ending which can leave you with mixed thoughts and feelings. To put this into the region of Clannad, Air or Kanon would be a complete overstatement; this anime has it good points but does nothing groundbreaking to stand out on its own. I would not recommend this personally, you’re not missing anything by not watching this show and you could get so much more from the likes of the previous three anime I mentioned as they are essentially the same genre.

Boy named Sana come back to his childhood hometown, where he meet his old friends. We have fun reunion with lot of comedy in it. But! We quickly know what happened in past. Momentaly its change into a drama. At first I think to drop this anime 'cause of that. But I watched it to very end. This anime can move everybody's to tears. Every character is unique, unrepeatable. We will not find here elaborate jokes or the situation, only concrete moments when we laugh and cry.

I began watching this anime after hearing the op.  In the op it showed the characters in a band.  I was dissapointed about the band not being in the series but I'm also into animes like this.  It's based on a visual novel.  It's got alot of drama in the series, I am drawn to sad animes.  This series was similar to School Days as well.  I cried many times while watching this series.  The character development is pretty good, Nanaka at first came off as a really cold character because Sana didn't remember her after 6 years,he had just returned to the city after moving away 6 years prior to the start of the series.  I found Aoi's voice to be really irritating and it didn't match her at all.  I liked this series alot and now I wish it could be released in America.  I'd recommend it to anybody who is into a drama, school life, psychological anime.

I must say that even though i saw this a while ago, I think about it all the time. It was truely a great anime! I hope i can only do it justice with this reveiw:)
First of all, when you read the synopsis, you'll get the impression of a high school drama. THERE IS SOOOO MUCH MORE!!!! This anime is dark, and yet light. If my memory serves me correctly, there are plenty of happy moments. But behind all of those happy moments lies a dark secret, and truth to be discovered. Reconsider this anime is you are casting it aside as another romance/high schoolanime. So many dark times, lies, betrayal, and moments that just shock you await. But also remember, not all is dark, there are happy moments too.


This anime is basically about friends helping out friends through rough times in their life. The story just screams the fact that a friend is there to listen to you, and to help you out and help you stay strong. The characters in this story all have their own struggles and inter turmoils that are expressed during the story. Very heartfelt and touching. It made me wanna text my best friend and tell her how much i loved her:) Beautiful friendships and relationships and moments that just make you wanna cry because your so happy for them and congradulate them for having such wonderful friends! I wish everyone had someone like the main characters of this anime! xD 


Also, Nanaka plays the violin. Being a violin player myself i felt connected to the anime:) She's also pretty. But she holds such sadness within her. Also, being able to relate to that, Nanaka's pain and sadness from the events in her life make the watcher want to give her a hug through their computer screen, and comfort her. Although Hidaka does a pretty good job! haha:)


The art is very good too:) I thought the scenes were very nice and the characters were well done:) Some of the moments were beautifully captured through the art! I applaud the artist:)


Also, the story line was fantastic! The synopsis doesn't do it justice. This anime is much more complex and intense then it has led you to believe. Take my advice and watch this anime. But come prepared with some tissues just incase! ;D


This was just me speaking my mind about this anime:) You don't have to follow my adviceto watch it )or use some tissues:P) but if you read this review wondering if you should watch it or thinking that it's not for you, I highly reccomend this anime:) But then again it's your choice:) Happy watching!

I only recently started watching anime in 2015 which means I never even heard of a lot of the older anime, for example Myself; Yourself which came out in 2007 and I never knew it existed. However because I enjoyed Anohana and Angel Beats one of my friends recommended I check out Myself; Yourself. I don't remember who recommended it to me, but boy do I wish I could thank them. Myself; Yourself was one of the best shows i've ever watched, from the characters to the AMAZING plot everything was perfect.
Myself; Yourself really made me fall in love with each and everyone of thecharacters, I actually felt these characters pain and wanted nothing more than for each of the characters to be as happy as they can possibly be. Even after everything they made each of the characters go through Myself; Yourself gives one of the most satisfying endings i've ever seen, after 12 episodes of peer sadness and despair they ended it off by showing that not everything is as bad as it seems and there's always light at the end of the tunnel...


When I saw this anime only had 13 episodes I was kind of weary as from my experience with 12-13 episode drama's, they never seem to be able to get the story across in that short amount of time. Myself; Yourself managed to get the story across perfectly in such a limited amount of time. I managed to feel like I actually knew all of the characters and felt sad seeing them go through some of the stuff they went through. Myself; Yourself deals with some more heavy topics such as family issues, depression and even suicide. Not too many anime's like to try and cover some of these heavier topics as anime's like this tend to go unseen compared to the cute-fun anime's that has swept the anime industry. I really respect Myself; Yourself for taking on these topics and dealing with them in such a fitting way. Myself;Yourself shows that even if you're depressed or having problems, your friends will always be there for you to help you through it all... 


Myself; Yourself is one of the best anime's I have watched to date as it goes places very few anime's are willing to go, very few anime's are willing to take on controversial topics as they're afraid they might mess up and choose to take on the easier approach of making a cute and fun anime. I really hope we'll get more anime's like this one but for now i'll gladly re watch Myself; Yourself hundreds of times.

In all honesty I gathered a couple anime to watch during lunch breaks.  I actually confused this one with a different one, and kept thinking to myself this is actually interesting but not at all like what I thought it would be.  So in all honesty I can say I was very happy I watched this, and I actually have issues spoiling the story for myself but because I thought it was a different story that never happened.  I thought some of the plot was just to foreshadowed and was easy to spoil for myself.  That being said I did notsee the ending happen.  Though I will admit the last episode was very powerful, the last scene in it was unneeded.  There are some shows that are so open ended and leave so much to your interpretation that to solidify an ending you must show it.  This was not one, when the second to last scene ended you pretty much could have guessed.  My only thought was they added in the last scene to also be like "Ow that is why they titled it that".  Beyond all that though if you want something that will entertain you and does not require much thought to keep up with this is a good show for short breaks.  But I will say it got me twice, where in all honesty I see where you could have pieced it together but I did not.  I really enjoy it when I do not see the story before it unfolds.  I did get most of it but maybe just a bit off and I love that.  If you love that then I would recommend you watch this.

As I'm writing this, I'm still collecting my thoughts on Myself;Yourself. The progression of the last few episodes has kind of left me in shock. A lot of the events were predictable based on the hints given away, by there were definitely moments that I never saw coming. I think it's a good time to pause, and evaluate the series as a whole.
Let us start with the better aspects of the show. When it comes down to it, Myself;Yourself is great at getting you involved with the story. The staff create emotional pivots that lock your emotions in with the developments occurring on screen. Althoughvery predictable, it was all the more satisfying as events transpired.The characters were likable....well, I'll go over Aoi a little bit in the negative portion, but overall they had good backstories and were consistent. The animation was fairly standard, good, but nothing spectacular. Oh, and wow. Nanaka is amazing at violin! 


Tisk, tisk, I must admit I was impressed by this series, but a few things chipped off some brownie points. Aoi was a decent character, but wow, she could really be annoying as hell. I found myself reciting words best left untyped at times when she was babbling on or making odd noises. The music was average to the series. The notable negative I can mention for it was the sound of a ... recorder? It was like 5th grade all over again. There was certainly room for more progression and development was well.


To put it into perspective, Myself;Yourself is a super deep and engaging work that will leave you deep and emotionally touched. It's a great coming of age drama/romance with deep backstories. Give it a whirl or at least an add to the plan to watch list! 


A grand total 8/10 Wrist Watches.

Good points that got me:
1. episode titles kinda catch you off guard: "Good Luck! Animenger!" when I knew this show is definitely a heavy hitter, emotional wise, but the lightheartedness was definitely on purpose. Also, "confession", seriously I thought the protagonist is finally confessing, but it's not JUST the confession of love, but something heavy yet understandable mixed in.
2. screen time for Aoi san/chan. Not just a yapper/side joke/ditz character, but she really is kind.
3. Aoi-san's mother got the best lines. The eternal narrator voice-over guy was in this show -> boosts fun factor by 9,000. (narrator for Hayate no Gotaku) The show has manynon-serious side to it, but not off putting. They actually make you laugh even when some of them are cliche. Because I totally believe in the situation that this could happen. \n
4. a feel of everyone is a main character. The little kid's arch, the twins arc, the weird hair girl's arc. yet still maintain a lead character so the story feels more like in the first person perspective. \n
5. a sense of something strange is going on but it's not bursting. this subtleness makes it easy for the audience, AND the character to be able to feel confused, making chances for mis-communications and thus conflicts and stories. Red herrings and truth mixed in one bag. \n
6. following up with the strangeness, the show resolves everything it proposed. In sometimes an extremely concise fashion. One line, or a look, a slip of tongue, a gesture. \n
7. devils in the detail/contrast. connecting previous established rule and apply new meanings is a great technique in hooking the audience. In the first couple of episodes, weird haired girl and the main dude were seen and misunderstood by Nanaka, and later on, the weird haired girl did something similar to what Nanaka did. What irony. Also in teacher's caramel, and later a role reversal in the twins arc. \n
8. Contrast. related to 7, one way to apply the technique is thru contrast. Opening sequence is the school festival with them all dancing and singing. Well, there's contrast with that and the show. Additionally, music is definitely an element that connected them all from the beginning till the end. I wish they had done the gold ribbon thing in the first episode at the end too. \n
9. There are so many moving pieces and yet the show was able to show them in one fell swoop and nothing felt really out of timeline or out of place. I should watch it again to see if there's any though.\n
10. the show's animation style puts me at ease, not too busy, not that bright, with the everyday cloudy grayish kind of look - perfect for a slice of life.. ahh, i mean, a drama. \n
11. no outright fan service. I say this despite the fact of the first episode when Aoi showed up and the five second bikini line up. This is a pretty serious show and it treats all its characters with due respect. \n
12- a bit rushed. Now this is a good point, combining with how I watch the series in three days. It kept up with my pace.\n\n
some points that annoyed me:\n
1- weird haired girl's arc. Not sure why would she do it in front of the main dude. Also in little kid's arc, why does the main dude get all the attention?\n
2- seriously can the little brother's blushing BE more annoying? \n
3- more BMG perhaps? I really want to hear more Nanaka's violin. Reminds me of G senjo no maou. \n\n\n
Quick MAL rundown:\n
story - 8. Enjoyable. Best thing is they resolved everything. \n
art - 8 . not everyone's cup of tea but it's relaxing for me. \n
sound - 5 well there's barely any.\n
charactet - 9. it's not about how I love this or that character (aoi: blue sama i get it now lol). but how the characters are presented and the lines they say, man i love the subtle and succinct method of molding characters. seems very natural. \n
enjoyment - 10. I ran through the whole show in three days. For reasons explained above, this is a very enjoyable show. I might buy the DVD and study them later. \n
Overall - 9. well, 10 is Monster, Madoka, and this show gets 9. To be honest I like more of the technical aspect of the show then the product. Umm, still a 9.

Overall: I thought overall, Myself; Yourself, was a very good anime, though the problem lies in the fact that it set itself up to be something extremely good, but didnt manage to deliver the amazingness that it seemed like it was going to... I would give it a 8.5, but you cant give a half score so it will be a 8.
Story: This is where the Myself; Yourself both stands out and fails in, though the story is not all too special in the beginning, they reveal more and more interesting pasts of the characters. Unfortunately, the ending was what did it in, they builtup the suspense and drama for the end, but didnt have anything that really wowed me, its like loading a giant firework, lighting the fuse, and it just kind of disappears, no giant awesome explosion or anything... for the story, you can feel that it is being rushed, especially near the end. it would have done much better if they didnt end it the way they did and made it a full 24-26 ep season instead of a half season series.


Art: Nice colorful environments and the level of detail for the background is very good, on rare occasions, you can notice that theres something in the art that is a little off if you pay very close attention to the art, but there is nothing really noticeable normally.


Sound: I liked the opening and the closing theme songs, however there are points once in a while where the BGM didnt really fit too well with the mood...


Character: Though most of the characters are generic anime romance personalities, I thought they worked quite well together, though they dont get very many points on being very original on character development...


Enjoyment: I thought it was well worth watching, though in the end the ending will most likely upset many viewers. Watching the story progress was quite entertaining, and if you take out the fact that the ending was rushed and out of character, its a great romance anime.

I've seen quite a few bad reviews for this, but I liked it. I liked it though. The only things I could say bad about it were filler and possible bad adaption from the VN. Not only did I like this show, but I could relate; that really sold me on it. In order to really like a romance, I need to cry and cry I did. 
I'd say a 9/10 for story. The story could've been slightly better for sure. The build up was a lot slower at first, and relied more on comedy than the plot; they fixed that over time. They dida decent job at bringing it together in 13 episodes.  I could definitely feel for it, but it took awhile to get there. It would have had a 10/10 story rating if there were more feels. \n
7/10 on animation. This is all about personal preference, and personally I'd say it's pretty standard for what it is. I could see similarities between Clannad and Chaos;Head art styles. I liked it, but it's not exactly the best art I've seen.\n
8/10 on sound. I liked the OP and liked the ending even better (then again, I'm a Kanako Ito fanboy). The music played during the show itself wasn't really prominent though. If that were better, it would get a better rating. \n
7/10 on characters. The characters could have been done a hell of a lot better. It seemed they rushed character development in the latter half of the show. Some argue that they didn't develop the characters enough, and that it was hard to connect because of this; I somewhat disagree. I could get a feel for them through their interactions and what was shown. There definitely would have been more feels if character development was more of a focus, for sure. I was fine with it as was though. \n
10/10 enjoyment. I really enjoyed Myself;Yourself as a rom com. It did everything right in my opinion. There was decent comedy, struggles, and romance. It had a conclusion. That's better than a lot of rom com VN adaptations. \n
10/10.\n

The art didn't shout out "cute!", but I don't know, it was very "calm" looking to me. Not too flashy, but not too boring either.
